subject: added support for Collection Functions
commitMessage:
added support for Collection Functions

new supported operations: min,max,sum,avg
new supported time scopes: interval,startup

added unit test to verify that each collection function returns correct
timestamp and value

Tested:
- POST/GET on telemetry features in bmcweb, no regression detected
- Using dbus API metric with collection function works as expected

Change-Id: Ib364c433915e07fd7a102f00109525362c40ab8a
Signed-off-by: Krzysztof Grobelny <krzysztof.grobelny@intel.com>

nit Consider to use namespace Metric here, up to you
Done
nit I guess you can move it to Metric class definition
Because there is forward declaration of CollectionData in hpp file this cannot be moved to class definition, it won't compile.
Ok. Thanks for explanation
Not all are used here. Is it required?
If we want to keep CollectionFunction, CollectionData then yes.
Collection* classes sounds ok. But the rest, like Function* (which I guess inherits from CollectionFunction) are not required.
There is dependency between them, so I have to either make all of them public or private.
Than I am ok to keep it as it is. It is not obvious what is the relation between those classes
Ack
maybe appendReading?
Removed, it is not used yet.
Did you move make_shared<Metric> to SetUp because of move operation? Maybe use ctor instead SetUp()? Using ctor instead  SetUp will allow you to remove TestMetric::SetUp() from 58 line
But that will break setup in 135 which assumes that sut object is not yet created when manipulating time using fake clock.
Ok, make sense to me. Thanks for explanation
const auto& ?
Done
Move these to metric.hpp L: 17?

It's here on purpose. Metric::Collection data is only defined in cpp file as a implementation detail. That's why destructor need to be defined here. Compiler won't know how to delete Metric::Collection outside of this translation unit.
Ack
add try-catch ?
Why? I don't see any possible throw inside.

if resultReadings.size() == 10 and collectionAlgorithms.size() < 10
I think collectionAlgorithms[i] will overflow, Correct?

In any case, it is a good habit to add `try-catch` when we operate the array.

Both arrays have same size. resultReadings is a copy of readings with updated timestamp. Both readings and collectionAlgorithms have same (sensors.size()) there is no way to overflow.

Let's consider we can try-catch here.
- We won't get error code on dbus, error will be silently discarded. 
- If something is thrown it will be silently handled somehow, but all we can do is silently discard it. Unit tests won't fail and CI won't detect this error.

If we keep this throw with our current test coverage if something is wrong here CI won't allow this change to be merged. Also other tools that are run on CI are able to detect potential memory issues here. If you want we can change [] to .at that should change potential crash or valgrind error to failed test due to uncatched exception.

Please take a look at TEST_P(TestMetricCalculationFunctions, calculatesReadingValue), Metric constructor and this code. There is no way that any exception is thrown here we have it covered in unit tests.

If we catch this exception here how are we supposed to test it?
Okay, I am fine
Ack

What happens if index > collectionAlgorithms.size()?

I think we can add try-catch ?

This exception should never happen, if it happens we need to detect it as fast as possible and fix it. If this throws we can consider whole telemetry not working, there is no recovery from it. That's why there is no catch.

There is bunch of unit tests that cover this case, if something is not right here CI will detect it.
as above
Ack
nit: This short form of double value initialization can be overlooked and misinterpreted, maybe you could use full double value here like 0.0 or use list initialization like double{0.}?
Done
No code update at this point here yet.
Unresolving, please comment if you intend to keep it without changing.

My bad, I forgot to git add this change.

Done.
Is this include actually needed here?
Done
No customized destructor defined, maybe you could keep this line in header file only?

It actually makes difference where it is defined. If you move it to .hpp files all member destructors will be inlined there. It will compile multiple times and need destructor code of all members.

In this case destructors of Metric::CollectionData, DataPoint, DataStartup, DataInterval are defined only this file and not available in .hpp file. This simply won't compile without moving this classes to .hpp file.
Ack
In this lambda there is no need do modify captured variable, could you therefore add 'const' to the parameter in findAssociatedData function signature?
Done
